S4.T1.caption: TABLE I: FNN properties.
S4.T1.table:
Input size 32
Output layer size 2
Hidden layer sizes 128,64,321286432128,64,32
Dropout rate 0.20.20.2
Activation function ReLU (hidden layer)
Softmax (output layer)
Loss function Crossentropy
Optimizer RMSprop
Number of parameters 14,626
references: To evaluate the effect of jamming attacks on DFL, we consider a transmitter that can transmit using either QPSK or BPSK modulation. We analyze phase shift and power level for raw I/Q data to obtain features that are used as the input to the DNN for DFL. We consider features for 161616 bits as one sample. For BPSK, there are 323232 features. For QPSK, we calculate two sets of phase shift and power level for 222 bits so that the number of features in a sample is also 323232. The output of the DNN is the classification label, i.e., ‘BPSK’ or ‘QPSK’. We use feedforward neural network (FNN) as the DNN with parameters shown in Table I.

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Attack performance for a random topology.
S4.T2.table:
Attack Convergence Minimum Average
algorithm time accuracy accuracy
No attack 497 94.00 94.94
Attack all links ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.00 71.95
Unlimited jamming range
MCBA 571 54.70 89.68
NDBA 571 54.70 89.68
Random 641 54.70 94.76
Limited jamming range
MCBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 51.10 76.77
NDBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.60 76.44
Random 842 87.50 93.04
references:
Table II shows the results for a randomly generated network.
When there is no attack, DFL can converge at time 497497497 (i.e., after 497497497 rounds) with minimum accuracy 94.00%percent94.0094.00\%.
If an adversary can jam all links, each node can only train a model using its own data. These models cannot converge in 100010001000 rounds. The performance can be very bad for some node(s). The minimum accuracy is 50.00%percent50.0050.00\%, which is the same as the performance of random guessing. The average accuracy is 71.95%percent71.9571.95\%, which is not high. This result shows the need of DFL to train a good model jointly.
For Scenario 111, all attacks increase the convergence time and reduce the performance.
The MCBA and the NDBA have the same performance and we find that they attack the same set of links.
The random attack, although is effective to reduce the minimum accuracy, is not very effective to reduce other nodes’ accuracy. That is, the average accuracy is 94.76%percent94.7694.76\%, which is almost the same as the average accuracy of no attack 94.94%percent94.9494.94\%.
For Scenario 222, all attacks again reduce the performance.
The NDBA is slightly better than the MCBA.
The random attack is not effective to reduce either the minimum accuracy or the average accuracy.
Comparing two scenarios, the attacks for Scenario 222 are more effective because for this scenario, jammers do not need to always attack a link in both directions.

S4.T3.caption: TABLE III: Attack performance for the line topology.
S4.T3.table:
Attack Convergence Minimum Average
algorithm time accuracy accuracy
No attack 602 87.40 88.22
Attack all links ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 56.10 70.14
Unlimited jamming range
MCBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 56.10 78.28
NDBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 56.10 78.28
Random ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 59.50 71.66
Limited jamming range
MCBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 56.10 70.40
NDBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 56.10 70.40
Random 602 87.40 88.22
references:
Table III shows the results for the line topology.
When there is no attack, DFL can converge at time 602602602 with minimum accuracy 87.40%percent87.4087.40\%.
For the worst case that an adversary can jam all links, the models cannot converge in 100010001000 rounds. The performance can be very bad for some node(s), as low as 56.10%percent56.1056.10\% accuracy, and the average accuracy is 70.14%percent70.1470.14\%.
For Scenario 111, all attacks increase the convergence time and reduce the performance.
The MCBA and the NDBA have the same performance and we find that they attack the same set of links.
The random attack is not very effective to reduce the minimum accuracy.
For Scenario 222, the MCBA and the NDBA again achieve the same performance.
The random attack has the same performance as no attack because the randomly deployed jammers cannot attack any link.

S4.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Attack performance for the star topology.
S4.T4.table:
Attack Convergence Minimum Average
algorithm time accuracy accuracy
No attack ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 69.80 84.30
Attack all links ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.40 80.37
Unlimited jamming range
MCBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.40 78.88
NDBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.40 78.88
Random ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 55.90 80.37
Limited jamming range
MCBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.90 64.14
NDBA ≥1000absent1000\geq 1000 50.90 64.14

references:
Table IV shows the results for the star topology.
DFL cannot converge in 100010001000 rounds even if there is no attack. Although the average accuracy 84.30%percent84.3084.30\% is good, the minimum accuracy is just 69.80%percent69.8069.80\%.
For the worst case that an adversary can jam all links, the performance can be very bad for some node(s), as low as 50.40%percent50.4050.40\% accuracy, and the average accuracy is 80.37%percent80.3780.37\%.
For Scenario 111, the MCBA and the NDBA have the same performance (minimum accuracy 50.40%percent50.4050.40\% and average accuracy 78.88%percent78.8878.88\%).
The random attack is not very effective to reduce both the minimum accuracy and the average accuracy.
For Scenario 222, the MCBA and the NDBA again achieve the same performance.
The random attack converges at time 270270270 with bad performance, i.e., accuracy results are still good (minimum accuracy 83.88%percent83.8883.88\%).

Table V shows the results for the ring topology.
DFL cannot converge in 100010001000 rounds even if there is no attack. The average accuracy is 84.11%percent84.1184.11\% and the minimum accuracy is 78.80%percent78.8078.80\%.
For the worst case that an adversary can jam all links, the performance can be very bad for some node(s), as low as 50.40%percent50.4050.40\% accuracy, and the average accuracy is just 63.72%percent63.7263.72\%.

For Scenario 222, the MCBA and the NDBA again achieve the same performance.
The random attack is not very effective to reduce the average accuracy.

S4.T6.table:

algorithm time accuracy accuracy
No attack 842 73.20 85.10

Unlimited jamming range

Table VI shows the results for the grid topology.
DFL converges at time 842842842 rounds when there is no attack. The average accuracy is 85.10%percent85.1085.10\% and the minimum accuracy is 73.20%percent73.2073.20\%.
For the worst case that an adversary can jam all links, DFL cannot converge in 100010001000 rounds.
The performance can be very bad for some nodes(s), as low as 50.40%percent50.4050.40\% accuracy, and the average accuracy is just 66.46%percent66.4666.46\%.
For Scenario 111, the MCBA and the NDBA have the same performance (converged at time 761761761 with minimum accuracy 51.80%percent51.8051.80\% and average accuracy 81.75%percent81.7581.75\%).
The random attack converges at time 558558558 but with bad performance, i.e., accuracy results are still good (average accuracy 84.90%percent84.9084.90\%).
For Scenario 222, all attacks making DFL not converged in 100010001000 rounds.
The MCBA is most effective (minimum accuracy 50.40%percent50.4050.40\% and average accuracy 67.98%percent67.9867.98\%).
The NDBA has slightly higher accuracy (minimum accuracy 51.80%percent51.8051.80\% and average accuracy 69.57%percent69.5769.57\%).
The random attack is not very effective to reduce the average accuracy.
